{{Infobox film | name = Hairspray | image = Hairspray poster.jpg | image_size = 215px | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[John Waters]] | producer = John Waters
[[Robert Shaye]]
[[Rachel Talalay]] | writer = John Waters | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Sonny Bono]] * [[Ruth Brown]] * [[Divine (performer)|Divine]] * [[Debbie Harry]] * [[Ricki Lake]] * [[Jerry Stiller]] * [[Ric Ocasek]] * [[Pia Zadora]]}} | music = [[Kenny Vance]] | cinematography = David Boner | editing = Janice Hampton | studio = [[Stephen Woolley|Palace Pictures]] | distributor = [[New Line Cinema]] | released = {{Film date|1988|2|16|Baltimore|1988|2|26}} | runtime = 92 minutes{{cite web|title=''HAIRSPRAY'' (PG)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/AFF061450/|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=1988-05-31|accessdate=2012-11-05}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $2 million | gross = $8.3 million }} '''''Hairspray''''' is a 1988 American [[Dance in film|dance]] [[comedy film]] written and directed by [[John Waters]], and starring [[Ricki Lake]], [[Divine (performer)|Divine]], [[Debbie Harry]], [[Sonny Bono]], [[Jerry Stiller]], Leslie Ann Powers, [[Vitamin C (singer)|Colleen Fitzpatrick]], and [[Michael St. Gerard]]. ''Hairspray'' was a dramatic departure from Waters's earlier works, with a much broader intended audience. ''Hairspray''{{'}}s [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|PG]] is the mildest rating a Waters film has received; most of his previous films were rated [[X rating|X]] by the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]]. Set in 1962 [[Baltimore, Maryland]], the film revolves around self-proclaimed "pleasantly plump" teenager Tracy Turnblad as she pursues stardom as a dancer on a local TV show and rallies against [[racial segregation]]. ''Hairspray'' was only a moderate success upon its initial theatrical release, earning a modest gross of $8 million. However, it managed to attract a larger audience on [[home video]] in the early 1990s and became a [[cult classic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hairspray.htm|title=Hairspray (1988)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2007-06-12}}''Hairspray'' at [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1009096-hairspray/ Rotten Tomatoes]; last accessed May 5, 2007. Most critics praised the film, although some were displeased{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} with the overall [[Camp (style)|campiness]]. The film ranks #444 on [[Empire (film magazine)|''Empire'' magazine]]'s 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/500/11.asp |title=Empire Features The 500 Greatest Movies of All Time |website=Empireonline.com |accessdate=August 14, 2011}} In 2002, the film was adapted into a [[Hairspray (musical)|Broadway musical of the same name]], which won eight [[Tony Award]]s, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] in 2003. A [[Hairspray (2007 film)|second film version]] of ''Hairspray'', an [[Film adaptation|adaptation]] of the stage musical, was also released by [[New Line Cinema]] in 2007, which included many changes of scripted items from the original. ==Plot== In Baltimore, Maryland in the year 1962, Tracy Turnblad and her best friend, Penny Pingleton, audition for ''The Corny Collins Show'', a popular [[Baltimore]] teenage dance show (based on the real-life ''[[The Buddy Deane Show|Buddy Deane Show]]''). Penny is too nervous and stumbles over her answers, and another girl, Nadine, is cut for being black (the show has a "Negro Day" on the last Thursday of every month, she is told). However, despite being overweight, Tracy is a strong enough dancer to become a regular on the show, infuriating the show's reigning queen, Amber Von Tussle, a mean, privileged, beautiful high school classmate whose racist parents, Velma and Franklin Von Tussle, own Tilted Acres Amusement Park and have banned African Americans from going there. Tracy steals Amber's boyfriend, Link Larkin, and competes against her for the title of Miss Auto Show 1963, fueling Amber's hatred of her. Tracy's growing confidence leads to her being hired as a plus-size model for the Hefty Hideaway clothing store owned by Mr. Pinky. She is also inspired to bleach, tease, and rat her [[big hair]] into styles popular in the 1960s. At school, a teacher brands her hairdo a "hair-don't" and sends her to the principal's office, from which Tracy is sent to [[special education]] classes, where she meets several black classmates who have been put there to hold them back academically. The students introduce Tracy to Motormouth Maybelle, an [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] record shop owner and host of the monthly "Negro Day" on ''The Corny Collins Show''. They teach Tracy, Penny, and Link dance moves and Penny begins an [[Interracial relationship|interracial romance]] with Motormouth Maybelle's son, Seaweed. This horrifies Penny's parents, Prudence and Paddy, who imprison their daughter in her bedroom and try to [[Brainwashing|brainwash]] her into dating white boys and oppose integration with the help of Dr. Frederickson, a [[quackery|quack]] [[Psychiatry|psychiatrist]]. Seaweed later helps her break out of the house and run away. It is implied that she will never return, as she has finally broken free from her parents. Undeterred, Tracy uses her newfound fame to champion the cause of [[racial integration]] with the help of Motormouth Maybelle, Corny Collins, his assistant Tammy, and her own [[Agoraphobia|agoraphobic]], slightly overbearing, overweight mother, Edna. After a [[race riot]] at Tilted Acres results in Tracy's arrest, the Von Tussles grow more defiant in their opposition to racial integration. They plot to sabotage the Miss Auto Show 1963 pageant with a bomb hidden in Velma's towering bouffant wig. The plan literally blows up in Velma's face when the bomb detonates prematurely, and the Von Tussles are dragged away by the Baltimore police. Tracy, who had won the crown but was disqualified for being in reform school, dethrones Amber after the governor of Maryland pardons her; Tracy then shows up at the pageant, integrates the show, and encourages everyone to dance. ==Cast== * [[Ricki Lake]] as Tracy Turnblad, an optimistic, aspiring teenager who hopes to dance on a TV show as well as promote integration. * [[Divine (performer)|Divine]] as Edna Turnblad, Tracy's kind, plus-sized mother who is ashamed of her obesity. Divine also plays Arvin Hodgepile, the rival TV station owner who is against racial integration for his studio. * [[Debbie Harry]] as Velma Von Tussle, Franklin's wife and Amber's mother. * [[Sonny Bono]] as Franklin Von Tussle, Velma's husband and Amber's father. * [[Jerry Stiller]] as Wilbur Turnblad, Tracy's loving, funny and encouraging father. * [[imdbname:0694572|Leslie Ann Powers]] as Penelope "Penny" Pingleton, Tracy's shy best friend. * [[Vitamin C (singer)|Colleen Fitzpatrick]] as Amber Von Tussle, snobby dancer on The Corny Collins Show. * [[Michael St. Gerard]] as Lincoln "Link" Larkin, a teenage heartthrob, Tracy's boyfriend, and Amber's ex-boyfriend. * [[imdbname:0697628|Clayton Prince]] as Seaweed J. Stubbs, Motormouth Maybelle's son who loves to dance. Seaweed is Penny's main love interest. * [[imdbname:0586933|Cyrkle Milbourne]] as L'il Inez Stubbs, Seaweed's little sister. * [[Ruth Brown]] as Motormouth Maybelle Stubbs, a friendly and strong-willed African American and mother of Seaweed and L'il Inez. * [[Shawn Thompson]] as Corny Collins, the eccentric host of The Corny Collins Show. * [[Mink Stole]] as Tammy, an employee and personal assistant to Corny Collins. * [[Jo Ann Havrilla|Joann Havrilla]] as Prudence Pingleton, Paddy's wife and Penny's overprotective controlling mother who doesn't approve of Penny dating Seaweed. * [[imdbname:0731042|Doug Roberts]] as Patrick "Paddy" Pingleton, Prudence's husband and Penny's no nonsense father who wants to protect Penny from Seaweed. * [[imdbname:0920863|Alan J. Wendl]] as Mr. Pinky, the owner of the Hefty Hideaway clothing store. * [[Toussaint McCall]] as himself (Though appearing as a man in his 50s, rather than in his 20s, as he would have been in 1962) * [[John Waters]] as Dr. Fredrickson, a psychiatrist who helps Prudence and Paddy try to brainwash Penny into only dating white boys. ;Council members * [[Josh Charles]] as Iggy * [[Jason Downs]] as Bobby * [[Holter Graham]] as I.Q. * Dan Griffith as Brad * Regina Hammond as Pam * Bridget Kimsey as Consuella * Frankie Maldon as Dash * Brooke Stacy Mills as Lou Ann * John Orofino as Fender * Kim Webb as Carmelita * Debra Wirth as Shelly ;Special appearances * [[Ric Ocasek]] as the [[Beatnik]] cat * [[Pia Zadora]] as the Beatnik chick ==Production== [[John Waters]] wrote the screenplay under the title of ''White Lipstick'', with the story loosely based on real events. The ''Corny Collins Show'' is based on the real-life ''[[The Buddy Deane Show|Buddy Deane Show]]'', a local dance party program which pre-empted Dick Clark's ''[[American Bandstand]]'' in the Baltimore area during the 1950s and early 1960s.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hairspray-Sonny-Bono/dp/B00006RZ9Y|title='Hairspray' DVD Commentary by: John Waters and Ricki Lake|author=[[John Waters]]; [[Ricki Lake]]|date=November 5, 2002|work=[[New Line Cinema|New Line Home Video]]}} Waters had previously written about ''The Buddy Deane Show'' in his 1983 book ''Crackpot: The Obsessions of John Waters.'' [[Principal photography]] took place in and around the Baltimore area during the summer of 1987.{{cite book|author=[[Robert Maier]]|date=2011|title=Low Budget Hell: Making Underground Movies with John Waters|url=|location=Davidson, North Carolina, U.S.A.|publisher=Full Page Publishing|pages=273–297|isbn=978-0-9837708-0-0}} The school scenes were filmed at [[Perry Hall High School]] with set locations including the library, a first-floor English class, and the principal's office.{{cite web|url=http://www.bcpl.info/info/history/hist_pe_schools.html |title=Perry Hall's Schools: The Heart of the Community |author=David Marks |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101004408/http://www.bcpl.info/info/history/hist_pe_schools.html |archivedate=January 1, 2009 }} In the scene set in the principal's office, the Harry Dorsey Gough (see [[Perry Hall Mansion]]) coat-of-arms that once hung in the main lobby can be seen through the doorway.{{cite web|url=http://www.perryhallmaryland.org/funfacts|title=Fun Facts About Perry Hall|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709085526/http://www.perryhallmaryland.org/funfacts|archivedate=2009-07-09|df=}} The scenes set at Tilted Acres amusement park were filmed at [[Dorney Park]] in [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]]. The film was [[Divine (performer)|Divine]]'s final film; he died three weeks after the film's release. ''Hairspray'' was his only film with Waters in which he didn't play the lead. Originally, Divine was considered to play both Tracy Turnblad and her mother Edna. Executives from New Line Cinema, the film's distributor, discouraged this concept, and it was eventually dropped.{{cite book|last1=Egan|first1=James|title=John Waters: Interviews|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|isbn=9781617031823|pages=xxiii|edition=Paperback}} Instead Divine played Edna Turnblad and Arvin Hodgepile, racist TV station owner. ===Deleted scenes=== A handful of [[Deleted scene|scenes were cut]] while in post-production, some of which explained certain elements seen in the film. The first scene occurs before Tracy and Penny go the Parkville VFW record hop. Tracy is required to start her first shift working in the Hardy-Har Joke Shop. But after managing to scare away all her customers she is excused to go to the hop. The joke shop customers are still listed in the end credits of the final cut. Another involves Tracy skipping school, stealing shoes from the Etta Gown Shop, and breaking into the Von Tussles' home, using Amber's hair bleach to bleach her hair in Amber's sink, thus explaining Tracy's change of hair color later in the film. Another deleted scene involved live roaches crawling out of Tracy's hair at Tilted Acres. The actual filmed scene of the cockroach crawling out of Tracy's hair is cut, but still included is Amber's horrified reaction. However, she is presumed to be joking and/or lying. When discussing his decision to ultimately cut the scene, Waters explained "[[Robert Shaye|Bob Shaye]], the head of New Line, probably correctly, said, 'This doesn't work. What is this, a [[Luis Buñuel|Buñuel]] movie?' [...] And he was probably right." A further excised scene sees Penny and Seaweed trying to take refuge at Nadine's home after Penny's escape. The final deleted scene was a musical number which involved the teens performing an obscure 1960s dance called "The Stupidity" at the auto show just prior to Tracy being released from reform school, but again, Waters ultimately decided it wasn't appropriate, stating, "[B]asically, I thought, you know, you don't want your leading man to look stupid right in the big finale." ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== ''Hairspray'' received three stars from critics [[Gene Siskel]] and [[Roger Ebert]].{{cite news| url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/hairspray-1988 | work=RogerEbert.com | title=Hairspray |last=Ebert |first=Roger |publisher=Ebert Digital LLC |date=February 26, 1988 |accessdate= April 10, 2018}} The film currently holds a 98% "fresh" rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 41 reviews with an average rating of 7.8/10. It is Waters' second-highest-rated film (behind ''[[Multiple Maniacs]]'') on the website. The critical consensus states that "''Hairspray'' is perhaps John Waters' most accessible film, and as such, it's a gently subversive slice of retro hilarity."{{rotten-tomatoes|1009096-hairspray|Hairspray}} John Waters wrote that his all-time favorite review of ''Hairspray'' was [[David Edelstein]]'s in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'': "A family movie both the Bradys and the Mansons could adore".{{cite book|author=Waters, John|title=Crackpot: The Obsessions of John Waters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tr7lYLTXmFYC|accessdate=27 September 2017|date=1 November 2007|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4165-9124-5|chapter=Finally, Footlights on the Fat Girls}} ===Box office=== ''Hairspray'' opened on February 26, 1988 in 79 North American theaters, where it grossed {{USD}}577,287 in its opening weekend. On March 11, it [[Wide release|expanded]] to 227 theaters, where it grossed $966,672 from March 11–13. It ended its theatrical run with $8,271,108.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=hairspray.htm |title=Hairspray (1988) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=August 14, 2011}} ===Awards=== The film was nominated for six [[Independent Spirit Award]]s, and the Grand Jury Prize at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095270/awards|work=IMDB|title= Awards for Hairspray}} ==Other works== ===Broadway musical=== {{Main|Hairspray (musical)}} In mid-2002, [[Margo Lion]] teamed with writers [[Marc Shaiman]] and [[Thomas Meehan (writer)|Thomas Meehan]] to turn ''Hairspray'' into a [[Broadway musical]] production. The show opened on August 15, 2002 starring [[Marissa Jaret Winokur]] as Tracy and [[Harvey Fierstein]] as Edna. The show went on to win eight [[Tony Awards]], including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]], in 2003. The show closed on January 4, 2009. ===2007 film adaptation=== {{Main|Hairspray (2007 film)}} In 2006, New Line Cinema joined forces with [[Adam Shankman]] to adapt the Broadway show into a movie musical. The film was released July 20, 2007, starring [[John Travolta]] as Edna, [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] as Velma, [[Christopher Walken]] as Wilbur, [[Amanda Bynes]] as Penny Pingleton, [[Brittany Snow]] as Amber Von Tussle, [[Queen Latifah]] as Motormouth Maybelle, [[James Marsden]] as Corny, [[Zac Efron]] as Link, and newcomer [[Nikki Blonsky]] as Tracy. The film had a $75 million budget and earned over $200 million worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hairspray07.htm |title=Hairspray (2007) |website=BoxOfficeMojo.com |accessdate=August 14, 2011}} ===2016 live television adaptation=== {{Main|Hairspray Live!}} [[NBC]] aired a special television event of the acclaimed musical on December 7, 2016, starring [[Harvey Fierstein]] as Edna, [[Ariana Grande]] as Penny Pingleton, [[Kristin Chenoweth]] as Velma, [[Martin Short]] as Wilbur, [[Dove Cameron]] as Amber Von Tussle, [[Jennifer Hudson]] as Motormouth Maybelle, [[Derek Hough]] as Corny, [[Garrett Clayton]] as Link, and newcomer Maddie Baillio as Tracy. It was well received by critics and was seen by 9.05 million viewers, with a ratings share of 2.3 in the 18–49 demographic, and a 5.9 overnight household rating. ==Soundtrack== {{Main|Hairspray (1988 soundtrack)}} The soundtrack was released in 1988 by [[MCA Records]]. The album featured one original song by [[Rachel Sweet]] and eleven other songs mostly from the early 1960s by [[Gene Pitney]], [[Toussaint McCall]] and [[The Ikettes]], among others. Two songs, "[[You Don't Own Me]]" and "Mama Didn't Lie", came out in 1964 and 1963 respectively. ;Additional songs Other songs appear in the film, but are not on the soundtrack, due to licensing restrictions, because many of the songs listed were on [[Cameo Parkway Records]], a recording label owned by Allen Klein.{{clarify|date=January 2016}} * "[[Limbo Rock]]" – [[Chubby Checker]] * "[[Let's Twist Again]]" - Chubby Checker * "[[The Banana Boat Song|Day-O]]" – [[Pia Zadora]] * "[[Duke of Earl]]" – [[Gene Chandler]] * "Train to Nowhere" – [[The Champs]] * "Dancin' Party" – Chubby Checker * "The Fly" – Chubby Checker * "The Bird" – The Dutones (not to be confused with [[The Five Du-Tones]], who are also featured on the soundtrack) * "[[Pony Time]]" – Chubby Checker * "Hide and Go Seek" – [[Bunker Hill (musician)|Bunker Hill]] * "[[Mashed Potato Time]]" – [[Dee Dee Sharp]] * "Gravy (For My Mashed Potatoes)" – Dee Dee Sharp * "Waddle, Waddle" – The Bracelets * "Do the New Continental" – [[The Dovells]] * "[[You Don't Own Me]]" – [[Lesley Gore]] * "Life's Too Short" – The Lafayettes ==Home media== ''Hairspray'' was issued for the first time on [[VHS]] and [[LaserDisc]] in 1989 by [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment|RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video]]. [[New Line Cinema|New Line]] reissued the film on VHS in 1996. The film was released on [[DVD]] by New Line in 2002. The disc included an [[audio commentary]] by John Waters and Ricki Lake and a [[Trailer (promotion)|theatrical trailer]]. It was released on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on March 4, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hairspray-Blu-ray-Divine/dp/B00GGT4OK6/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1393101203&sr=8-10&keywords=hairspray|title=Hairspray|author=|date=4 March 2014|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2018|via=Amazon}} ==See also== {{Portalbar|1980s|Television in the United States|Comedy}} * [[Cross-dressing in film and television]] * [[Racial integration]] * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement in popular culture]] * [[Multiculturalism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0095270}} * {{mojo title|hairspray}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|1009096-hairspray}} * {{metacritic film|hairspray-1988}} {{John Waters}} {{Hairspray}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hairspray}} [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:1980s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American satirical films]] [[Category:American teen comedy films]] [[Category:American teen romance films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by John Waters]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in film]] [[Category:Culture of Baltimore]] [[Category:Films adapted into plays]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films about television]] [[Category:Films set in Baltimore]] [[Category:Films set in 1962]] [[Category:Films shot in Baltimore]] [[Category:Films shot in Maryland]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Films about interracial romance]]

'''Hera Gallery''' is a small, non-profit [[artist cooperative]] in [[Wakefield, Rhode Island]] USA. Created within the context of the [[Feminist art movement in the United States|feminist art movement]], Hera Gallery was a pioneer in the genesis of [[artist-run space]]s. Its founding objective in 1974 was to provide a venue for [[women artists]], under-represented at the time in commercial galleries. As the cultural climate changed in the 1980s, the gallery broadened its scope to include visual artists of both genders. Concurrently, Hera curated more topical exhibitions with a broadened spectrum of social awareness and activism. To this day, the gallery provides contemporary artists with the opportunity to address cultural, social, and political issues and to maintain creative control.
==History== Hera Gallery was created in 1974, the year that the alternative gallery movement burst beyond major cities and into locations as remote as a village in rural southern Rhode Island.<ref name="Broude 1994 112">{{cite book | last = Broude | first = Norma | authorlink = |author2=[[Mary D. Garrard]] | title = The Power of Feminist Art: The American Movement of the 1970s, History and Impact | publisher = Henry N. Abrams | year = 1994 | location = New York | pages = 112 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8109-3732-8 }}</ref> It was conceived from a [[consciousness-raising]] group consisting mostly of artists, and often associated with the nearby [[University of Rhode Island]], that started meeting in 1969.<ref name="Yow 1989 1–2,4,6">{{cite book | last = Yow | first = Valerie R. |author2=[[Natalie Boymel Kampen]] | title = The History of Hera: A Women's Art Cooperative, 1974-1989 | publisher = Hera Educational Foundation| year = 1989 | location = Rhode Island | pages = 1–2, 4, 6 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-9625352-0-6 }}</ref> One of the common topics to discuss were the difficulties of balancing the domestic responsibilities of being wife and mother with a professional artistic career.<ref name="Pamela H. 1991 51–2">{{cite journal|title=The History of Hera: A Woman's Art Cooperative, 1974-1989|journal=Woman's Art Journal|year=1991|first=Simpson|last=Pamela H. |volume=12|issue=2|pages=51–2|id= |format=|doi=10.2307/1358294|jstor=1358294|publisher=Woman's Art, Inc.|last2=Yow|first2=Valerie Raleigh|last3=Kampen|first3=Natalie Boymel }}<!--|accessdate=2007-12-07--></ref> The women discussed the difficulty in having their work represented in Manhattan galleries, where apparent sexism from gallery owners caused their work to be disregarded.<ref name="Yow 1989 1–2,4,6"/> Hera Gallery was thus created in order to foster a professional community of women artists, in the vein of other recently established women-run artist cooperatives,<ref name="Pamela H. 1991 51–2"/> such as New York City's [[A.I.R. Gallery]]. At the time, a Providence Journal writer commented that "...a women's art center named after a bitchy Greek goddess and housed in a barn that used to be a laundry is New England's only art gallery completely owned and controlled by women..." <ref name="Broude 1994 112"/> [[Image:Heragalleryexterior.JPG|thumb|right|Photograph of Hera Gallery's exterior]]
==Organizational structure== Initially the organization of Hera Gallery consisted of non-hierarchical egalitarian committees, influenced by feminist ideals.<ref name="Yow 1989 1–2,4,6"/><ref name="Pamela H. 1991 51–2"/> As the gallery grew, its board of directors, once only represented by artist-members, was appended with a community Advisory Board from 1986–2000, according to the gallery's unpublished “Addendum to the History of Hera”. Furthermore, when the Advisory Board was discontinued in 2000, the Board of Directors began including external community members (Addendum). Since 1992 (Addendum) there has also been a Gallery Director part-time paid position.<ref name="membership guidelines">{{cite web|url=http://heragallery.org/pdf/heramembershipguidelines.pdf |title=membership guidelines |accessdate=2007-12-07 |date=May 2000 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018191913/http://www.heragallery.org/pdf/heramembershipguidelines.pdf |archivedate=2007-10-18 |df= }}</ref>
Hera Gallery offers its members an annual solo exhibition, inclusion in group exhibitions, curatorial opportunities, and positions on the Board of Directors.<ref name="membership guidelines"/> It serves the surrounding community by “encouraging ethnic and cultural diversity in both audience and program development.<ref name="membership guidelines"/> ”
==Developments== Since its inception, Hera Gallery has resided in a building that was a garage in the 1920s, then a laundromat, and later a flea market, before finally being outfitted by the founding artists and their loved ones. Its landlord throughout this time was a sympathetic URI professor who kept the rent low for them.<ref name="Yow 1989 1–2,4,6"/> After his recent demise, the family put the land on the market but waited for a buyer whose plan included preserving the gallery.<ref>{{cite news | first=Mark | last=Schieldrop | title=Mixed use explored for Hera’s, Phil’s | date=2006-09-22 | publisher= | url =http://scindependent.com/articles/2006/09/22/local/astory.txt | work =The South County Independent | pages = | accessdate = 2007-12-07 | language = }}</ref> In September 2007 it was announced that a buyer plans on demolishing the existing building to create a [[mixed-use development]] including residential condominiums and inclusion of the gallery.<ref>{{cite news | first=Katie | last=Mulvaney | title=Condos slated to replace gallery, diner | date=2007-09-14 | publisher= | url =http://www.projo.com/ri/southkingstown/content/SC_SKHERA_09-14-07_D3746UH.355227d.html | work =The Providence Journal | pages = | accessdate = 2007-12-07 | language = }}</ref>

{{short description|There is no major conflict between the religious beliefs of Hinduism and acceptance of the science of evolution}} {{Creationism2}} [[Hinduism]] includes a range of viewpoints about the [[origin of life]], [[creationism]] and [[evolution]]. There is no single story of creation, due to dynamic diversity of Hinduism, and these are derived from various sources like [[Vedas]], some from the [[Brahmana]]s, some from [[Puranas]]; some are philosophical, based on concepts, and others are narratives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailyo.in/variety/hindusim-world-creation-universe-brahma-vishu-shiva/story/1/19522.html|title=How did the world come into being according to Hinduism?}}</ref> The [[Rigveda]] mentions the ''[[Hiranyagarbha]]'' ("golden embryo") as the source of the creation of the Universe, similar to the [[world egg]] motif found in the [[creation myth]]s of many other civilizations. It also contains a myth of [[proto-Indo-European religion|proto-Indo-European]] origin, in which the creation arises out of the [[dismemberment]] of a cosmic being (the [[Purusha]]) who is sacrificed by the gods.<ref name="Jan2007"/> As for the creation of the primordial gods themselves, the [[Nasadiya Sukta]] of Rigveda takes a near-[[agnostic]] stand, stating that the Gods came into being after the world's creation, and nobody knows when the world first came into being.<ref>Griffith, Ralph T.H. (Transl.): [http://www.sacred-texts.com/hin/rigveda/rv10129.htm Rigveda Hymn CXXIX. Creation] in Hymns of the Rgveda, Vol. II, 1889-92. Munshiram Manoharlal Publishers Pvt. Ltd., New Delhi, 1999.</ref> In the later [[Puranas|Puranic]] texts, the creator god [[Brahma]] is described as performing the act of 'creation', or more specifically of 'propagating life within the universe'. Some texts consider him equivalent to the Hiranyagarbha or the Purusha, while others state that he arose out of these. Brahma is a part of the [[trimurti|trinity]] of gods that also includes [[Vishnu]] and [[Shiva]], who are responsible for 'preservation' and 'destruction' (of the universe) respectively.
Many Hindu texts mention the [[Hindu cosmology|cycle of creation and destruction]]. The [[Shatapatha Brahmana]] states that the current human generation descends from [[Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]], the only man who survived a [[flood myth|great deluge]] after being warned by the God. This legend is comparable to the other [[List of flood myths|flood legends]], such as the story of the [[Noah's Ark]] mentioned in the [[Bible]] and the [[Quran]].<ref name="Sunil1999">{{cite book | author=Sunil Sehgal | title=Encyclopaedia of Hinduism: C-G | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zWG64bgtf3sC&pg=PA401 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | year=1999 | publisher=Sarup & Sons | isbn=978-81-7625-064-1 | page=401 }}</ref>
Hindus find support for, or foreshadowing of evolutionary ideas in [[Hindu scriptures|scriptures]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.well.com/user/jct/science.html | title=Science and spirituality: Any Points of Contact? The Teachings of U.G.Krishnamurti: A Case Study |last=Moorty | first=J.S.R.L.Narayana| work = Krishnamurti Centennial Conference| accessdate=2008-12-26 |date=May 18–21, 1995|quote=Hinduism has its own version of evolution, which agrees with the scientific theory that evolution is from the simple to the complex and from the homogeneous to the heterogeneous}}</ref> For example, the concept of [[Dashavatara]] can be seen as having some similarities to Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.The [[Matsya|first incarnation of Vishnu]] in the form of a fish resembles the evolutionary origin of fish in the [[Silurian Period]].
In a survey of 909 people, 77% of its respondents in India agreed that enough scientific evidence exists to support [[Darwinism|Charles Darwin’s Theory of Evolution]], and 85% of God-believing people said they agree with evolution as well.<ref name="ncse.com">{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/07/opinions-evolution-from-ten-countries-004885|title=Opinions on evolution from ten countries - NCSE|publisher=|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Hamilton">{{cite news| url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/faith/article2100585.ece | title = One in seven Britons believe in creationism over evolution | location=London | work=The Times | first=Fiona | last=Hamilton}}</ref> According to the survey conducted by [[Pew Forum]] in the [[United States]], 80% of Hindus agree that evolution is the best explanation for the origin of human life on earth.<ref name="pewforum.org">[http://pewforum.org/Science-and-Bioethics/Religious-Differences-on-the-Question-of-Evolution.aspx Religious Groups: Opinions of Evolution], [[Pew Forum]] (conducted in 2007, released in 2008)</ref> However, in India, there were minimal references to Darwinism in the 1800s. Elements of Victorian England opposed the idea of Darwinism. Hindus already had present notion of common ancestry between humans and animals. The Hindu dharma believes that the gods have animal features, showing a theory that humans can be reborn again as animals or with their features.<ref name="Gosling 345–347-348–353">{{cite journal|last=Gosling|first=David|title=Darwin and the Hindu Tradition: Does What Goes Around Come Around?|journal=Zygon|date=June 2011|volume=46|issue=2|pages=345–347–348–353|url=http://authenticate.library.duq.edu/login?url=http%3a%2f%2fsearch.ebscohost.com%2flogin.aspx%3fdirect%3dtrue%26db%3drfh%26AN%3dATLA0001843790%26site%3dehost-live|accessdate=2014-01-24|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9744.2010.01177.x}}</ref>
== Hindu creationism ==
According to [[Hindu]] [[creationism]] all [[species]] on earth including [[humans]] have "devolved" or come down from a high state of pure [[consciousness]]. Hindu creationists claim that species of [[plants]] and [[animals]] are material forms adopted by pure consciousness which live an endless cycle of births and rebirths.<ref>Science & Religion: A New Introduction, Alister E. McGrath, 2009, p. 140</ref> [[Ronald Numbers]] says that: "Hindu Creationists have insisted on the antiquity of humans, who they believe appeared fully formed as long, perhaps, as trillions of years ago."<ref>The creationists: from scientific creationism to intelligent design, Ronald L. Numbers, 2006, p. 420</ref> Hindu creationism is a form of [[old earth creationism]]. According to Hindu creationists the [[universe]] may even be older than billions of years. These views are based on the [[Vedas]] which depict an extreme antiquity of the universe and history of the [[earth]].<ref>James C. Carper, Thomas C. Hunt, The Praeger Handbook of Religion and Education in the United States: A-L, 2009, p. 167</ref><ref>A history of Indian philosophy, Volume 1, Surendranath Dasgupta, 1992, p. 10</ref>
=== Creation myths ===
Hinduism is a conglomeration of distinct intellectual or philosophical points of view, rather than a rigid common set of beliefs.<ref>{{cite book | title=Alone in Unity: Torments of an Iraqi God-Seeker in North America | first=Faris | last=Georgis | publisher=Dorrance Publishing | year=2010 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vFZrxLjtiI8C&pg=PA62 | page=62 | isbn=1-4349-0951-4}}</ref> As a result, the [[Hindu texts]] do not provide a single canonical account of the creation; they mention a range of theories of the creation of the world, some of which are contradictory.<ref name="Robert1999">{{cite book | author=Robert M. Torrance | title=Encompassing Nature: A Sourcebook | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uc246yZO0qEC&pg=PA121 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 April 1999 | publisher=Counterpoint Press | isbn=978-1-58243-009-6 | pages=121–122}}</ref>
==== Rigveda ====
The [[Purusha Sukta]] of the earliest Hindu text [[Rigveda]] mentions [[Purusha]], primeval cosmic being.<ref name="SNSadasivan2000">{{cite book | author=S. N. Sadasivan | title=A Social History Of India | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Be3PCvzf-BYC&pg=PA227 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 January 2000 | publisher=APH Publishing | isbn=978-81-7648-170-0 | pages=226–227 }}</ref> Purusha is described as all that has ever existed and will ever exist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sacred-texts.com/hin/rigveda/rv10090.htm|title=Rig Veda: Rig-Veda, Book 10: HYMN XC. Puruṣa.|publisher=|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref> This being's body was the origin of four different kinds of people: the [[Brahmin]], the [[Kshatriya|Rajanya]], the [[Vaishya]], and the [[Shudra]].<ref name=Tignor2014>"Worlds Together Worlds Apart", Fourth Edition, Beginnings Through the 15th century, Tignor, 2014, pg. 5</ref> Viraj, variously interpreted as the [[world egg|mundane egg]]<ref name="SNSadasivan2000"/> (see [[Hiranyagarbha]]) or the twofold male-female energy, was born from Purusha, and the Purusha was born again from Viraj. The gods then performed a [[yajna]] with the Purusha, leading to the creation of the other things in the manifested world from his various body parts and his mind. These things included the animals, the Vedas, the [[Varna]]s, the celestial bodies, the air, the sky, the heavens, the earth, the directions, and the Gods [[Indra]] and [[Agni]]. It is likely that this myth has [[proto-Indo-European religion|proto-Indo-European]] origins, as it is similar to other myths found in the Indo-European cultures, in which the creation arises out of the dismemberment of a divine being (cf. [[Ymir]] of the [[Norse mythology]]).<ref name="Jan2007">{{cite book | author=Jan N. Bremmer | title=The Strange World of Human Sacrifice | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tPjVJF8roYC&pg=PA170 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | year=2007 | publisher=Peeters Publishers | isbn=978-90-429-1843-6 | pages=170–}}</ref>
The concept of Purusha is similar to the concept of [[Brahman]] described in the later texts.<ref name="Roshen2011">{{cite book | author=Roshen Dalal | title=Hinduism: An Alphabetical Guide | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DH0vmD8ghdMC&pg=PA318 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=5 October 2011 | publisher=Penguin Books India | isbn=978-0-14-341421-6 | pages=318–319}}</ref>{{rp|318}} As for the creation of the primordial beings (such as the gods who performed the sacrifice of the Purusha), the [[Nasadiya Sukta]] states:<ref name="McNamaraWildman2012">{{cite book|author1=Patrick McNamara|author2=Wesley J. Wildman|title=Science and the World's Religions [3 Volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3MK5u1_7CLYC&pg=PA180|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=19 July 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-38732-6|pages=180–}}</ref>
{{quotation|<poem> Who really knows, and who can swear, How creation came, when or where! Even gods came after creation’s day, Who really knows, who can truly say When and how did creation start? Did He do it? Or did He not? Only He, up there, knows, maybe; Or perhaps, not even He. </poem> |Rig Veda 10.129.1-7 }}
Rigveda (10.121) also mentions the [[Hiranyagarbha]] (literally, golden embryo/womb/[[world egg|egg]]) that existed before the creation. This metaphor has been interpreted differently by the various later texts. The [[Samkhya]] texts state that Purusha and the [[Prakṛti|Prakriti]] made the embryo, from which the world emerged. In another tradition, the creator god [[Brahma]] emerged from the egg and created the world, while in yet another tradition the Brahma himself is the Hiranyagarbha.<ref name="Edward2009">{{cite book | author=Edward Quinn | title=Critical Companion to George Orwell | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hZET2sSUVsgC&pg=PA188 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 January 2009 | publisher=Infobase Publishing | isbn=978-1-4381-0873-5 | page=188 }}</ref> The nature of the Purusha, the creation of the gods and other details of the embryo creation myth have been described variously by the later Hindu texts.
The early hymns of Rigveda also mention [[Tvastar]] as the first born creator of the human world.<ref>"[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/594460?uid=3739448&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=3737720&uid=4&sid=21101565303097 The Creation Myth of the Rig Veda]" by W. Norman Brown. Journal of the American Oriental Society, Vol. 62, No. 2 (Jun., 1942), pp. 85-98.</ref>
Recounting the creation of gods, the Rig Veda does seem to affirm ‘’creatio ex nihilo’’. Rig Veda 10.72 states: {{quotation|<poem> देवानां नु वयं जाना पर वोचाम विपन्यया | उक्थेषुशस्यमानेषु यः पश्यादुत्तरे युगे || बरह्मणस पतिरेता सं कर्मार इवाधमत | देवानाम्पूर्व्ये युगे.असतः सदजायत || देवानां युगे परथमे.असतः सदजायत | तदाशा अन्वजायन्त तदुत्तानपदस परि ||
1. LET US with tuneful skill proclaim these generations of the Gods, That one may see them when these hymns are chanted in a future age. 2 These Brahmaṇaspati produced with blast and smelting, like a Smith, Existence, in an earlier age of Gods, from Non-existence sprang. 3 Existence, in the earliest age of Gods, from Non-existence sprang. Thereafter were the regions born. This sprang from the Productive Power.<ref>Rig Veda 10.72 translation by R.T.H. Griffith (1896)</ref></poem> }}
==== Brahmanas ==== [[File:The fish avatara of Vishnu saves Manu during the great deluge.jpg|thumb|right|The [[matsya|fish avatara]] of [[Vishnu]] saves [[Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]], the progenitor of the existing human race, during the [[flood myth|great deluge]].]] The [[Shatapatha Brahmana]] mentions a story of creation, in which the [[Prajapati]] performs [[tapas (Sanskrit)|tapas]] to reproduce himself. He releases the waters and enters them in the form of an egg that evolves into [[Brahmanda|the cosmos]].<ref name="WhitePollak2010">{{cite book | author1=Merry I. White | author2=Susan Pollak | title=The Cultural Transition: Human Experience and Social Transformation in the Third World and Japan. Edited by Merry I White, Susan Pollak | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H5Up5YECUX8C&pg=PA183 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=2 November 2010 | publisher=Taylor & Francis | isbn=978-0-415-58826-3 | page=183 }}</ref> The Prajapati emerged from the golden egg, and created the earth, the middle regions and the sky. With further tapas, he created the devas. He also created the [[asura]]s, and the darkness came into the being.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|102–103}} It also contains a story similar to the other [[List of flood myths|great flood stories]]. After the great flood, [[Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]] the only surviving human, offers a sacrifice from which Ida is born. From her, the existing human race comes into the being.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|102–103}}
==== Upanishads ====
The [[Aitareya Upanishad]] (3.4.1) mentions that only the "[[Ātman (Hinduism)|Atman]]" (the Self) existed in the beginning. The Self created the heaven (''Ambhas''), the sky (''Marikis''), the earth (''Mara'') and the underworld (''Ap''). He then formed the Purusha from the water. He also created the speech, the fire, the prana (breath of life), the air and the various senses, the directions, the trees, the mind, the moon and other things.<ref name="MaxMuller2004">{{cite book | author=F. Max Muller | title=The Upanishads, Vol I | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6VFU0jK7UC&pg=PA228 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=30 June 2004 | publisher=Kessinger Publishing | isbn=978-1-4191-8641-7 | pages=228 }}</ref>
The [[Brihadaranyaka Upanishad]] (1.4) mentions that in the beginning, only the Atman existed as the Purusha. Feeling lonely, the Purusha divided itself into two parts: male ("pati") and female ("patni"). The men were born when the male embraced the female. The female thought "how can he embrace me, after having produced me from himself? I shall hide myself." She then became a cow to hide herself, but the male became a bull and embraced her. Thus the cows were born. Similarly, everything that exists in pairs, was created. Next, the Purusha created the fire, the [[soma (drink)|soma]] and the immortal gods (the [[deva (Hinduism)|devas]]) from his better part. He also created the various powers of the gods, the different [[varna in Hinduism|classes]], the [[dharma]] (law or duty) and so on.<ref>[http://sacred-texts.com/hin/sbe15/sbe15055.htm Fourth Brâhmana] in Brihadaranyaka Upanishad, Fourth Brahmana. Translated by Max Müller as The Upanishads, Part 2 (SBE15) [1879].</ref> The [[Taittiriya Upanishad]] states that the being (''sat'') was created from the non-being. The Being later became the ''Atman'' (2.7.1), and then created the worlds (1.1.1).<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}} The [[Chandogya Upanishad|Chhandogya]] states that the Brahma creates, sustains and destroys the world.<ref name="ANPrasad2007">{{cite book | author=S.K. Paul, A.N. Prasad | title=Reassessing British Literature: Pt. 1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hpzrfJr-IlEC&pg=PA91 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 November 2007 | publisher=Sarup & Sons | isbn=978-81-7625-764-0 | pages=91 }}</ref>
==== Later texts ==== [[File:An attempt to depict the creative activities of Prajapati.jpg|thumb|350px|left|An attempt to depict the creative activities of Prajapati; a steel engraving from the 1850s]] Belief in evolution is among the [[Samkhya]] philosophy. In the [[Samkhya]] philosophy, evolution is symbolized by the Sanskrit term parinama. Many Hindu reformers compare this term and philosophy with Darwinism. The prominent Vivekananda, based most of his cosmological and biological ideas off of the [[Samkhya]].<ref name="Gosling 345–347-348–353"/> The [[Samkhya]] texts state that there are two distinct fundamental eternal entities: the Purusha and the [[Prakriti]]. The Prakriti has three [[guṇa|qualities]]: ''[[sattva]]'' (purity or preservation), ''[[rajas]]'' (creation) and ''[[tamas (philosophy)|tamas]]'' (darkness or destruction). When the equilibrium between these qualities gets broken, the act of creation starts. ''Rajas'' quality leads to creation.<ref name="Joshi2005">{{cite book | author=Dinkar Joshi | title=Glimpses Of Indian Culture | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-fw-0iBvmMAC&pg=PA32 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 January 2005 | publisher=Star Publications | isbn=978-81-7650-190-3 | page=32 }}</ref>
The later texts such as the [[Puranas]] identify the Purusha with the [[God in Hinduism|God]]. In many Puranic notes, [[Brahma]] is the creator god.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}} However, some Puranas also identify Vishnu, Shiva or Devi as the creator.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}}
In [[Garuda Purana]], there was nothing in the universe except the [[Brahman]]. The universe became an expanse of water, and in that Vishnu was born in the golden egg. He created Brahma with four faces. Brahma then created the devas, asuras, pitris and manushas. He also created the rakshasas, yakshas, gandharvas. Other creatures came from the various parts of his body (e.g. snakes from his hair, sheep from his chest, goats from his mouth, cows from his stomach, others from feet). His body hair became the herbs. The four varnas came from his body parts and the four Vedas from his mouths. He created several sons from his mind, Daksha, Daksha's wife, Manu Svaymbhuva, his wife Shatarupta and the rishi Kashypa. Kashypata married thirrteen of Daksha's daughter and all the devas and the createures were born through them.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}} Other Puranas and the Manu Smriti mention several variations of this theory.
In [[Vishnu Purana]], the Purusha is same as the creator deity [[Brahma]], and is a part of [[Vishnu]].<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|319}} The [[Shaivism|Shaivite]] texts mention the Hiranyagarbha as a creation of [[Shiva]].<ref name="Edward2009"/> According to the [[Devi-Bhagavata Purana]] Purusha and Prakriti emerged together and formed the [[Brahman]], the supreme universal spirit that is the origin and support of the universe.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|319}}
The Advaita Vedanta states that the creation arises from Brahman, but it is illusory and has no reality. (Vivarta)<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{realmente p|103}}
===Hindu cosmological view===
Many Hindu philosophies mention that the [[Hindu cycle of the universe|creation is cyclic]].<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|104}} According to the [[Upanishad]]s, the universe and the Earth, along with humans and other creatures, undergo repeated cycles (''[[pralaya]]'') of creation and destruction. A variety of myths exist regarding the specifics of the process, but in general the Hindu view of the cosmos is as eternal and cyclic. The later puranic view also asserts that the universe is created, destroyed, and re-created in an eternally repetitive series of cycles. In Hindu cosmology, a universe endures for about 4,320,000,000 years (one [[day of Brahma]], the creator or ''kalpa'')<ref>A survey of Hinduism, [[Klaus K. Klostermaier]], 2007, pp. 495-496</ref> and is then destroyed by fire or water elements. At this point, Brahma rests for one night, just as long as the day. This process, called ''pralaya'' (cataclysm), repeats for 100 Brahma years (311 trillion, 40 billion human years) that represents Brahma's lifespan.
== Modern Interpretations of Scriptural archetypes ==
Most Hindus accept the theory of biological evolution.<ref name="ncse.com"/><ref name="Hamilton"/><ref name="pewforum.org"/> They either regard the scriptural creation theories as allegories and metaphors, or reconcile these legends with the modern theory of evolution.
===Dashavatara=== {{main|Dashavatara#Evolutionary interpretation}}
The order of the [[Dashavatara]] (ten principal [[avatar]]s of the god [[Vishnu]]) is interpreted to convey Darwin's evolution.<ref name="Chandra1998">{{cite book|author=Suresh Chandra|title=Encyclopaedia of Hindu Gods and Goddesses|year=1998|publisher=Sarup & Sons|isbn=978-81-7625-039-9|pages=298}}</ref><ref name="Krishna2010">{{cite book|author=Nanditha Krishna|title=Sacred Animals of India|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-306619-4|page=7}}</ref> British geneticist and evolutionary biologist [[J. B. S. Haldane]] opined that they are a true sequential depiction of the great unfolding of evolution. Like the evolutionary process itself, the first avatar of God is a fish - [[Matsya]], then comes the aquatic reptile turtle, [[Kurma]], then a mammal - the boar [[Varaha]], then [[Narasimha]], a man-lion being, [[Vamana]], the dwarf then the rest four are humans; Kalki is not yet born.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Cover Story: Haldane: Life Of A Prodigious Mind | journal=[[Science Reporter]] | year=1992 | volume=29 | pages=46 |publisher=Council of Scientific & Industrial Research}}</ref> Various thinkers and authors like [[Helena Blavatsky]], [[Monier Monier-Williams]], [[Nabinchandra Sen]], [[C. D. Deshmukh]] have associated the Dashavatara with evolution.
===Vanara=== [[File:Building of Rama's Bridge.jpg|thumb|right|The Hindu epics mention an ape-like humanoid species called the [[vanara]]s.]]
The [[Sanskrit]] epics of the Hindus mention several [[exotic tribes of ancient India|exotic creatures]] including ape-like humanoids.<ref>J. K. Trikha, A study of the Ramayana of Valmiki, Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, 1981</ref> Some Hindus see this as a proof of the historicity of their mythological characters and as support for the theory of evolution in their texts. The [[Ramayana]] speaks of the [[Vanaras]], an ape-like species with human intelligence, that existed millions of years ago. According to the Ramayana alongside these [[ape-men]] existed [[modern humans]]. Thus, according to these ancient writings, the status of such creatures was a state of coexistence rather than evolution.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Tribute to Hinduism: Thoughts and Wisdom Spanning Continents and Time about India and Her Culture|page=386|first=Sushama|last=Londhe|year=2008|quote= For example, the Ramayana speaks of the Vanaras, a species of apelike men that existed millions of years ago.|publisher=Pragun Publications}}</ref>
==Hindu opposition to Christian creationism== While the [[Creation–evolution controversy]] has seen much debate in the US and other countries, it is an insignificant issue in India, because of its Hindu-majority population.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Balaram|first = P|title = Editorial| journal = [[Current Science]] | volume = 86| issue = 9| year = 2004| url = http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/may102004/1191.pdf| pages = 1191–1192}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last =Coleman |first = Simon |author2=Carlin, Leslie |title = The Cultures of Creationism: Anti-evolutionism in English-speaking Countries |chapter = The cultures of creationism: Shifting boundaries of belief, knowledge and nationhood |publisher = Ashgate Publishing| page = 3| year = 2003|isbn = 0-7546-0912-X}}</ref> Hindus are among many faiths that have expressed apprehension about efforts to teach [[Christian]] creationism in public schools in the US.<ref>''"Christian agenda worries other faiths: push for intelligent design seen by some as imposing Christianity on others"'', Jim Baker, Lawrence World – Journal, May 12, 2005. See [http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2005/may/12/christian_agenda_worries article on LJ world]</ref> One objection to the teaching of creationism based on the religious texts of a particular faith is that in a pluralistic society this can result in the imposition of one religion.<ref>{{cite web| title = The debate over evolution in Kansas public schools| url = http://www.pluralism.org/research/reports/white/|last = White| first = Aaron| publisher = The Pluralism Project at Harvard University| accessdate = 2008-12-26}}</ref>
